title: Bud Grant
summary: Harold Peter "Bud" Grant Jr. (born May 20, 1927) is a former head coach and player of American football, Canadian football, and a former player in the National Basketball Association (NBA). Grant served as the head coach of the Minnesota Vikings of the National Football League (NFL) for 18 seasons; he was the team's second (1967â€“83) and fourth (1985) head coach, leading them to four Super Bowl appearances, 11 division titles, one league championship and three National Football Conference championships.[1] Before coaching the Vikings, he was the head coach of the Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian Football League (CFL) for ten seasons, winning the Grey Cup four times. Grant is the most successful coach in Vikings history,[2] and the fifth most successful professional football coach overall with a combined 286 wins in the NFL and CFL.[3] Grant was elected to the Canadian Football Hall of Fame in 1983[4] and to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1994.[5]  He was the first coach to guide teams to the Grey Cup and the Super Bowl, the only other being Marv Levy.
